segment.source: Change your coordinate system
segment.target: Change your coordinate system

segment.source: One difference that sometimes confuses early port efforts is the change from OpenGL's traditional right-handed coordinate system to Direct3D's default left-handed coordinate system.
segment.target: One difference that sometimes confuses early port efforts is the change from OpenGL's traditional right-handed coordinate system to Direct3D's default left-handed coordinate system.

segment.source: This change in coordinate modeling affects many parts of your game, from the setup and configuration of your vertex buffers to many of your matrix math functions.
segment.target: This change in coordinate modeling affects many parts of your game, from the setup and configuration of your vertex buffers to many of your matrix math functions.

segment.source: The two most important changes to make are:
segment.target: The two most important changes to make are:

segment.source: Flip the order of triangle vertices so that Direct3D traverses them clockwise from the front.
segment.target: Flip the order of triangle vertices so that Direct3D traverses them clockwise from the front.

segment.source: For example, if your vertices are indexed as 0, 1, and 2 in your OpenGL pipeline, pass them to Direct3D as 0, 2, 1 instead.
segment.target: For example, if your vertices are indexed as 0, 1, and 2 in your OpenGL pipeline, pass them to Direct3D as 0, 2, 1 instead.

segment.source: Use the view matrix to scale world space by -1.0f in the z direction, effectively reversing the z-axis coordinates.
segment.target: Use the view matrix to scale world space by -1.0f in the z direction, effectively reversing the z-axis coordinates.

segment.source: To do this, flip the sign of the values at positions M31, M32, and M33 in your view matrix (when porting it to the Matrix type).
segment.target: To do this, flip the sign of the values at positions M31, M32, and M33 in your view matrix (when porting it to the Matrix type).

segment.source: If M34 is not 0, flip its sign as well.
segment.target: If M34 is not 0, flip its sign as well.

segment.source: However, Direct3D can support a right-handed coordinate system.
segment.target: However, Direct3D can support a right-handed coordinate system.

segment.source: DirectXMath provides a number of functions that operate on and across both left-handed and right-handed coordinate systems.
segment.target: DirectXMath provides a number of functions that operate on and across both left-handed and right-handed coordinate systems.
